title: 112_hr2826
content: The Act titled "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" provides payroll tax forgiveness for hiring combat veterans. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" offers a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2011 and 2012, where wages paid by qualified employers to qualified individuals are exempt from taxes for services performed during this period. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" provides a tax exemption for wages paid by qualified employers to qualified individuals who begin employment with them. Qualified employers exclude the United States, States, political subdivisions, or their instrumentalities, except for public institutions of higher education. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" offers a tax exemption for wages paid by qualified employers to individuals who meet specific criteria, including being a current member of the National Guard or a veteran, having returned from a deployment of at least 180 days, and not being hired to replace another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" provides a tax exemption for wages paid by qualified employers to eligible individuals. Qualified employers can elect to not apply this subsection. The term "wages" excludes payments to qualified individuals hired by a qualified employer within a 1-year period unless the employer makes an election not to. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" allows for a tax exemption on wages paid by qualified employers to eligible individuals. The Act also includes provisions for transfers to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Additionally, the Act applies to Railroad Retirement Taxes. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" includes a special tax rate for certain individuals hired in 2011 and 2012 by qualified employers, with a specific applicable percentage for compensation paid during this period. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" defines a qualified individual as someone who starts working for a qualified employer between June 30, 2011, and January 1, 2013, and is a current member of the National Guard, reserve component of the Armed Forces, or a veteran who returned from a deployment of at least 180 days in support of a contingency operation within 18 months before starting employment. The "Combat Veterans Back to Work Act of 2011" defines a qualified individual as someone who starts working for a qualified employer between June 30, 2011, and January 1, 2013, and is a current member of the National Guard, reserve component of the Armed Forces, or a veteran who returned from a deployment of at least 180 days in support of a contingency operation within 18 months before starting employment. Under section 502(f) of title 32, United States Code, certain conditions must be met for the employer to qualify, and an election can be made to opt out of the subsection. Additionally, appropriations are made to the Social Security Equivalent Benefit Account. The Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 (45 U.S.C. 231n-1(a)) authorizes appropriations to offset revenue reductions caused by amendments. These appropriations will be transferred from the general fund to replicate transfers that would have occurred without the amendments. The effective date for the amendments is after the enactment of the Act, applying to wages and railroad retirement taxes paid thereafter. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of newly hired veterans. The current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria, including being employed for at least 52 consecutive weeks. The current year business credit will be increased for retained workers meeting specific criteria, including 80% wage retention in the last 26 weeks. Unused credits cannot be carried back before enactment. Possessions with mirror tax systems will receive payments for losses due to this section. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine and pay amounts to possessions without mirror tax systems equal to the benefits residents would have received under this section if a mirror code tax system was in place. The Secretary of the Treasury will distribute payments to possessions of the United States with an approved plan to promptly distribute payments to residents. No increase in the credit against United States income taxes will be allowed for individuals eligible for a payment under the plan. The term "possession of the United States" includes Puerto Rico and the Northern Mariana Islands. The term "mirror code tax system" refers to the income tax system of a possession if residents' tax liability is determined by US income tax laws. The tax laws of the United States apply to possessions as if they were part of the US. Payments are treated according to specific rules under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Tax Act of 2009.
